study_goal: The researchers aimed to classify and understand the mechanisms of various compensation strategies used by Parkinson's disease patients to improve their gait impairments.
results_summary: The study identified 59 unique compensation strategies, classified into 7 categories, which appear to work by allocating attention to gait, introducing goal-directedness, and using less automatized motor programs. These strategies may help patients and clinicians manage gait impairment more effectively.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of noninvasive interactive neurostimulation (NIN) versus a sham device in improving functional impairment, reducing pain, and hastening return to sports in athletes with grade I or II lateral ankle sprains.
results_summary: Group I (NIN) showed better improvement in functional impairment (Inability Walking Scale), reduced pain (visual analogue scale), and lower daily intake of etoricoxib 60 mg compared to Group II (sham). Athletes in Group I also resumed sports activities faster.
population_specificity: Contact sport athletes with grade I or II lateral ankle sprains (n=61).
effective_dosage: Not specified (NIN treatment details not provided).
study_duration: 10 sessions over 2 weeks, with follow-ups at 30 days post-therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the responsiveness of outcome measures for assessing pain and function in individuals with osteoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
results_summary: The study found that the FHSQ pain subscale, FFI-RS pain subscale, and 100-mm VAS of pain severity while walking were the most responsive outcome measures, showing large or very large effect sizes. Sample size calculations indicated 20-33 participants per group would be needed to detect minimal important differences.
population_specificity: 88 patients (mean age 57.2 ± 10.2 years) with osteoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a prediction model for peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) in children with spina bifida, considering factors like peak workload, heart rate, age, sex, and physical activity level.
results_summary: The study developed a promising prediction model for VO2peak in children with spina bifida, showing high adjusted R² (0.933) and small mean differences between measured and predicted values. Further validation is needed before clinical implementation.
population_specificity: Children with spina bifida

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether detrended fluctuation analysis (DFA) applied to short stride time series (3-min trials) reliably reflects the fractal dynamics of longer time series (15-min trials) in gait variability.
results_summary: The study found that α-DFA values from 3-min walking trials were inconsistent both within trials and when compared to a 15-min trial, indicating unreliability for short time series. Additionally, α-DFA values from the first 150 strides of the 15-min trial did not match those from the full trial, suggesting DFA may not be suitable for assessing gait in individuals unable to perform 500 continuous strides.
population_specificity: 12 people with Parkinson's disease, 14 healthy older adults, and 14 healthy young adults.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking trials: five 3-min and one 15-min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of active travel interventions, such as walking school buses and educational strategies, on increasing physical activity and fitness in primary school children.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in active travel outcomes favoring the intervention, with walking school buses and educational strategies being the most effective. However, overall study quality was weak, and further high-quality research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Primary school children aged 4 to 11 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess cardiorespiratory fitness and physical strain during conventional prosthetic rehabilitation for individuals with lower limb amputation.
results_summary: The study found that cardiorespiratory fitness was low at the start of rehabilitation and did not improve, with physical strain during rehabilitation being insufficient to enhance aerobic capacity. The results highlight the need for individualized physical training modules.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb amputation undergoing inpatient prosthetic rehabilitation.
study_duration: Duration of inpatient rehabilitation (specific length not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of decentralized caregiver workstations in inpatient units on staff outcomes, particularly collaboration/communication and walking.
results_summary: The study found limited and inconsistent results regarding the effects of decentralized unit design on staff outcomes, including walking. The overall strength of evidence was rated as very low quality.
population_specificity: Staff in inpatient hospital units with decentralized caregiver workstations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a walking-adaptability assessment could better identify prospective fallers and risk factors for future falls compared to generic fall-risk factors alone.
results_summary: The study found that obstacle-avoidance success rate and normalized walking speed during goal-directed stepping, along with fall history, correctly classified prospective fallers and predicted future falls. Including walking-related fall-risk factors improved faller identification over generic factors alone.
population_specificity: Stroke patients, Parkinson's disease patients, and controls (30 participants per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate differences in mobility levels using the ADAMO system and compare its association with frailty against a traditional physical measure (400m walk test).
results_summary: Frail participants spent more time in Low Activity and less in Moderate and Vigorous Activity compared to robust participants. The ADAMO system's mobility index was associated with total, physical, and social frailty, while the 400m walk test was only associated with total and physical frailty.
population_specificity: 25 community-dwelling older adults (71±6 years; 60% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of robot-assisted locomotor training on walking function, lower extremity muscle strength, and balance in patients with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in walking function, muscle strength, and balance in both groups, with no statistically significant differences between the intervention and control groups for walking function or muscle strength. However, postural control declined significantly in the intervention group compared to controls.
population_specificity: 24 subjects with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (American Spinal Injury Association Impairment Scale grades C or D, >2 years post-injury).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between knee extension strength and gait performance with walking aids in patients with dementia, as well as identify threshold levels of strength to predict gait performance.
results_summary: The study found that knee extension strength significantly predicted gait performance with walking aids in dementia patients, with specific strength thresholds (0.17, 0.43, and 0.57 Nm/kg) correlating to 80% independence probability for walking with a walker, cane, or without aid, respectively.
population_specificity: 56 hospital inpatients with dementia.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study measured strength, not administered dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of multicomponent exercise, including walking, on frailty and related adverse outcomes in elderly residents of long-term nursing homes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a lower prevalence of frailty, maintained functional ability, fewer falls during the intervention period, and lower mortality compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly men and women aged 70+ in long-term nursing homes, capable of standing and walking independently for at least 10 meters.
effective_dosage: Individualized and progressive multicomponent exercise at moderate intensity (specific walking dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of high-purity synthetic trans-capsaicin (CNTX-4975) for reducing chronic moderate-to-severe osteoarthritis-associated knee pain during walking.
results_summary: CNTX-4975 showed dose-dependent pain reduction, with the 1.0 mg dose significantly improving pain through 24 weeks, while the 0.5 mg dose showed improvement at 12 weeks but not at 24 weeks. Adverse events were similar between the placebo and 1.0 mg groups.
population_specificity: Patients aged 45-80 years with stable knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Single intraarticular injection of 0.5 mg or 1.0 mg CNTX-4975.

study_goal: The researchers compared the efficacy and efficiency of two TAGteach error-correction procedures for teaching beginner yoga poses, with walking mentioned as one of the areas where TAGteach has been previously found effective.
results_summary: The study found that both TAGteach error-correction procedures were effective for teaching yoga poses, but the relative efficiency was unclear. Walking was noted as an area where TAGteach has improved performance, though no new walking-specific results were reported.
population_specificity: 4 novice adult yoga practitioners

study_goal: To determine if task-specific training, such as treadmill and over-ground walking, improves mobility in individuals with progressive neurological conditions like Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Treadmill training improved walking velocity, stride length, and step length in Parkinson's disease and walking endurance in multiple sclerosis, but had no effect on cadence or walking endurance in Parkinson's disease. Over-ground walking did not improve mobility in either condition.
population_specificity: Individuals with progressive neurological conditions (Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify which elements of physical rehabilitation programs improve mobility in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: PwMS who improved mobility received more individual therapy sessions. Resistance training was more common in the improved mildly disabled group, while aerobic training was more common in the improved moderately-severely disabled group.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) from 17 European centers, divided into mild and moderate-severe disability subgroups.
study_duration: Not specified (program elements included number of weeks and sessions, but exact duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize visual disorders affecting posture and balance in patients with neurological injuries and explore emerging therapies like prism treatment.
results_summary: The study found that gait and body position abnormalities correlate with focal neurological injury (stroke) and that visual vertigo can occur in traumatic brain injury patients despite normal visual function. Prism treatment shows therapeutic potential for posture and balance issues linked to visual neglect.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological injuries (e.g., stroke, traumatic brain injury) and visual vertigo or neglect.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of new drug discovery methods for treating neglected tropical diseases, particularly leishmaniasis.
results_summary: The study found that phenotypic screening based on intracellular parasite infections is a key tool in antileishmanial drug discovery, but hit discovery rates for leishmaniasis lag behind other neglected diseases. It advocates for new screening methods that incorporate the host's immune system to improve clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on drug discovery methods, not a specific human population).

study_goal: To compare gait and cognitive performance during dual tasks in children with cerebral palsy (CP) versus typically developing children.
results_summary: Gait performance decreased in both groups as cognitive load increased during dual tasks, with children with CP showing greater difficulties. The study suggests that dual-task conditions may underestimate daily-life challenges for children with CP.
population_specificity: 18 children with cerebral palsy (7 girls, 11 boys; median age 12 years) and 19 typically developing controls (9 girls, 10 boys; median age 12 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify neural changes associated with participation in a multicomponent walking aid program (ADSTEP) in people with multiple sclerosis using resting state functional MRI.
results_summary: Following ADSTEP participation, functional connectivity between supplementary motor areas and primary somatosensory cortices/putamen increased, while connectivity with the cerebellum decreased, suggesting supraspinal sensorimotor neuroplasticity. The study supports the potential of task-oriented walking aid training for mobility interventions.
population_specificity: Fourteen people with multiple sclerosis who used walking aids and reported at least one fall in the prior year.
effective_dosage: Six weekly progressive task-oriented walking aid training sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether overground bionic ambulation (OBA) enhances cardiometabolic challenge during walking in individuals with motor-incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI) compared to overground walking.
results_summary: The study found that OBA provided a higher cardiometabolic challenge for the participant with lower walking capacity, enabling sustained exercise, while it was less effective for the participant with higher walking capacity. The cardiometabolic response to OBA varied based on functional walking ability.
population_specificity: Two individuals (one man, one woman) with chronic motor-incomplete paraplegia due to SCI.
study_duration: 6 minutes per walking condition (OBA and overground)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an attention-demanding walking intervention could improve gait performance, reduce fall risk, and affect cholinergic activity in individuals at risk of falls.
results_summary: Treadmill training with non-immersive virtual reality improved obstacle negotiation, increased cholinergic activity (measured via SAI), and reduced falls compared to treadmill training alone. Greater SAI increases correlated with better gait performance and fewer falls.
population_specificity: 24 Parkinson's disease participants and 15 older adults at risk of falls.
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 6 weeks.
study_duration: 6 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic utility of observing patients' behavior, posture, and gait in waiting rooms for identifying movement disorders.
results_summary: The study presents observational examples of how patients' movements, posture, and behavior in waiting rooms can provide diagnostic clues for movement disorders, emphasizing the importance of early observation before formal examination.
population_specificity: Patients with potential movement disorders in clinical waiting rooms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess continuous step count activity remotely among individuals with MS for 1 year and determine how average daily step count is associated with other measures of MS disability.
results_summary: A decreasing average daily step count was associated with worsening clinic-based and patient-reported outcomes, even when traditional disability measures remained stable. Participants with a baseline step count below the median had higher odds of clinically meaningful disability worsening at 1 year.
population_specificity: 95 adults with relapsing or progressive MS who could walk more than 2 minutes with or without an assistive device.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of heel lifts on lower limb biomechanics and muscle function during walking and running.
results_summary: Heel lifts affected specific biomechanical parameters, such as swing phase duration and ankle dorsiflexion angle, with some statistically significant effects. However, the clinical relevance of these effects requires further investigation.
population_specificity: Asymptomatic participants, those with restricted ankle joint dorsiflexion, and individuals with haemophilia.
effective_dosage: Heel lifts of 5 mm to 5 cm, varying by study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the sources of heterogeneity in the effectiveness of robotic rehabilitation, particularly focusing on lower limb walking, through meta-regression analysis.
results_summary: For lower limb walking, opposing linear relationships were found between subgroups (therapy ratio = 0 had a negative relationship, while therapy ratio > 0 had a positive relationship). The spread of effect sizes suggested variability in robotic device effectiveness, with conventional training combined with robotic training generally yielding positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-regression based on prior systematic review data).
study_duration: Duration of intervention group therapy (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Guided Self-rehabilitation Contract method versus conventional therapy alone in improving active function in patients with chronic stroke-induced hemiparesis over a one-year period.
results_summary: The study compared two rehabilitation methods, finding that the Guided Self-rehabilitation Contract method, involving daily antagonist-targeting exercises and motivational guidance, was tested against conventional therapy, with primary outcomes focusing on ambulation speed and upper limb function. Secondary measures included cost of care, physiological cost index, quality of life, and psychological impact.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic hemiparesis (>1 year post-stroke) from six tertiary rehabilitation centers.
effective_dosage: Two monthly home visits for the experimental group, with daily self-rehabilitation programs prescribed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a tool (ACT) for assessing the effectiveness of Ponseti treatment for clubfoot in children of walking age in low-resource settings.
results_summary: The ACT tool demonstrated 79% sensitivity and 100% specificity in identifying children needing further intervention, with excellent inter-observer agreement. Children who completed two or more years of bracing were four times more likely to achieve a successful outcome (ACT score ≥9).
population_specificity: Children with congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) in low-resource settings, specifically in Africa.
study_duration: Follow-up conducted in 2017 for children treated between 2011 and 2013.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) on post-stroke recovery of lower limb motor function.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that rTMS significantly improved lower limb motor function (SMD = 0.66) and was deemed safe, though the evidence was limited by potential bias.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 10-week Nordic walking program could improve employee well-being at work, specifically reducing burnout and increasing vigor, compared to other leisure activities or a control group.
results_summary: The study investigated the effects of Nordic walking on burnout and vigor but did not report specific results in the abstract; it focused on testing psychological and physiological mechanisms through which physical activity might influence these outcomes.
population_specificity: Employees of the authors' University (N=140).
effective_dosage: Two Nordic walking sessions per week.

study_goal: To assess the effects of adaptive bungee trampoline training on muscle strength, balance, and functional mobility in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Lower limb muscle strength improved in 3 children, balance and functional strength improved in 2 children, and all participants showed clinically significant increases in goal attainment. No adverse effects were reported, and adherence and enjoyment were high.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy, aged 6 to 11 years (n=4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manual therapy combined with a 10-minute treadmill walking program could mitigate age-related declines in lung function and compare the effects of different manual therapy techniques.
results_summary: The study compared walking alone (Ex) to walking combined with joint mobilization (MB + Ex) or manipulation (MT + Ex). Results focused on lung function, chest wall expansion, and quality of life, but specific outcomes for walking alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy males and females aged 50-65 with no history of respiratory disease.
effective_dosage: 10-minute treadmill walking program, administered six times over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of daily undulating periodization (DUP) and nonperiodized (NP) resistance training programs on body composition and physical function in older women.
results_summary: The study found that NP improved multiple physical function measures (countermovement jump, timed "Up and Go" test, walking speed, and one-leg-stand), while DUP only improved TUG performance. Neither program significantly altered body composition.
population_specificity: Healthy community-dwelling older women aged 60-79 years.
effective_dosage: Twice weekly sessions over 22 weeks; NP: 3 sets of 8-10 reps at "difficult" intensity (RPE 5-6); DUP: one session at "moderate" intensity (RPE 3) performed as fast as possible, and one session similar to NP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early provision of ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) reduces falls and near falls in post-stroke patients compared to delayed provision.
results_summary: The early AFO group experienced significantly more falls (11 vs. 4) in the first eight weeks, with 63.6% occurring without wearing AFOs, primarily during transfers and standing among non-independent walkers. No differences were found for near falls in the first eight weeks or for falls/near falls in the follow-up period (weeks 9-52).
population_specificity: Unilateral hemiparetic stroke patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (AFO provision timing: early at week 1 vs. delayed at week 9).
study_duration: 52 weeks (with comparisons in weeks 1-8 and follow-up in weeks 9-52).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the maintenance of weight, diet, and physical activity outcomes, including walking, following an extended contact intervention (GHSH) compared to standard care.
results_summary: The study found that participants receiving the extended contact intervention (GHSH) showed sustained improvements in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA), including walking, compared to standard care, though weight regain was delayed rather than prevented.
population_specificity: Adults with a mean age of 53.4 years and a baseline BMI of 29.2 kg/m² who completed a lifestyle telephone coaching program.
study_duration: 6 months of intervention, with follow-up at 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functional outcomes of exercise, including walking, for patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty (THA).
results_summary: The study found that exercise significantly improved walking speed, Harris hip score, abduction strength, pain relief, and reduced hospital stay length compared to the control group, though no significant difference was observed in the physical activity scale.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total hip arthroplasty (THA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining an 8-week rehabilitation program with immediate soymilk ingestion improved functional outcomes in chronic stroke patients compared to rehabilitation alone.
results_summary: The rehabilitation program improved functional outcomes, and soymilk ingestion further enhanced hand grip strength, walking speed, walking performance per unit lean mass, and 6-minute walk performance, but did not affect SPPB total score or lean mass.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (age 57-84 yrs; time since stroke onset: 2-19 yrs)
effective_dosage: Not specified (soymilk or placebo ingested immediately after exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if text message reminders could improve adherence to acetaminophen treatment and affect pain intensity during walking in postoperative knee surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the intervention and control groups in missed acetaminophen doses, pain intensity during walking, or unscheduled healthcare contacts, though there was a nonsignificant trend toward better adherence in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Outpatients undergoing arthroscopic knee surgery (n=134).
study_duration: Assessed on the fourth postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a multimodal exercise program, including walking, on trunk muscle morphology, strength, and functional ability in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that trunk training combined with walking-balance exercises increased rectus abdominis size compared to walking-balance training alone, suggesting enhanced trunk muscle morphology. Functional ability and balance were primary outcomes, but specific walking-related results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥60 years (mean age 69.8, 59.4% female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week exercise program with walking and balance exercises).
study_duration: 12 weeks (followed by a 6-week walking-only detraining phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in outcomes, including walking speed (Timed 25-foot walk), between older MS patients who continued versus discontinued immunomodulating disease-modifying therapy (DMT).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in walking speed (T25FW) between patients who continued or discontinued DMT. Only the EQ-5D quality of life measure showed significant differences, with continuers having lower scores compared to those before discontinuation.
population_specificity: MS patients aged 60 or older who had been on DMT for at least 2 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate effects of healthy walking on arterial stiffness parameters in subjects with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that healthy walking at low-moderate intensity significantly reduced arterial stiffness parameters (CAVI and pulse pressure) and lowered blood pressure in the lower extremities, with greater benefits observed in males.
population_specificity: 89 subjects with type 2 diabetes, aged 40-70 years.
effective_dosage: 4 km of healthy walking at low-moderate intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 12-week exercise program (EP) focusing on hip abductor and knee extensor strength could improve gait biomechanics in children and adolescents with obesity.
results_summary: The EP increased hip abductor strength and reduced maximum hip adduction and pelvic drop during walking, but did not improve self-rated knee function, pain, or discomfort. Effects were small but indicated potential to counteract biomechanical malalignments.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity (EP group n=19, control group n=16).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily protein supplementation could enhance lean body mass, muscle strength, and physical performance in physically active older adults with low habitual protein intake during walking exercise training.
results_summary: Protein supplementation led to a larger increase in relative lean body mass and a greater reduction in fat mass compared to placebo, though no differences were observed in muscle strength or physical performance improvements between groups. Walking exercise training alone improved physical performance, lean body mass, and reduced fat mass.
population_specificity: Physically active older adults (median age 69, 82% male) training for a multi-day walking event with low habitual protein intake (<1.0 g/kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute transcriptional effects of regular active breaks (light- or moderate-intensity walking) during prolonged sitting on adipose tissue in overweight/obese adults.
results_summary: Breaking up prolonged sitting with walking led to differential regulation of adipose tissue metabolic and inflammatory pathways, enhanced insulin signaling, and modulation of adipocyte cell cycle, suggesting beneficial physiological effects. The study identified 36 differentially expressed genes between sitting and active break conditions.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults (n=8)
effective_dosage: 2-minute bouts of light- or moderate-intensity treadmill walking every 20 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify non-cognitive symptom clusters, including walking-related symptoms, in prodromal and early stages of neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: Walking was grouped into a symptom cluster consistent with an "SN Motor Phenotype," alongside balance, falls, and other motor-related symptoms, suggesting its relevance in synucleinopathies like Parkinson's Disease.
population_specificity: Patients receiving routine clinical care for memory disorders, categorized as Cognitively Normal, Detectable Cognitive Impairment, or Mild Cognitive Impairment due to AD/PD/LBD or NOS pathology.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise, including walking, could effectively improve symptoms in patients with constipation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise, including walking, significantly improved gastrointestinal symptoms in constipation patients, with a relative risk of 1.97 (95% CI: 1.19, 3.27). However, methodological limitations prevent definitive conclusions about the intervention's real effect.
population_specificity: 680 participants across nine randomized controlled trials, primarily involving aerobic exercise (including walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality of studies investigating gait characteristics in CKD patients, identify gait parameters associated with fall risk, and highlight gaps in current research.
results_summary: The study found that CKD progression is associated with slower walking speed, but most studies neglected spatiotemporal gait variables. No studies analyzed the relationship between gait parameters and fall risk.
population_specificity: Patients with Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD), particularly in advanced stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a 12-month exercise intervention, including walking and strength training, on endocrine-related and overall quality of life in breast cancer survivors experiencing aromatase inhibitor-induced arthralgia.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in overall quality of life, breast cancer-specific, endocrine-specific, and fatigue-specific subscales compared to the usual care group, with stronger effects observed at 12 months versus 6 months.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors currently receiving aromatase inhibitors and experiencing at least mild arthralgia.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of aerobic exercise (e.g., treadmill walking) and 2 strength-training sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between knee pain and objectively measured daily walking levels in adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that knee pain was not associated with daily walking levels in individuals with mild-to-moderate knee osteoarthritis. Covariates like age, BMI, and season were predictors of physical activity, but pain measures showed no significant association.
population_specificity: 59 individuals (48 women; mean age 61.1 ± 6.4 years, mean BMI 28.1 ± 5.6 kg/m²) with mild-to-moderate, symptomatic knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of multi-component interventions, including walking, to increase physical activity or reduce sedentary behavior among office-workers to improve mental health and cognition.
results_summary: The study design compares two multicomponent interventions (one focusing on physical activity, including walking, and the other on reducing sedentary behavior) with a control group, but specific results regarding walking's effects are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adult office-workers from two large Swedish companies.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions include motivational counselling, gym access, and organized lunch walks).
study_duration: 6 months (with follow-up measurements every 6 months for 24 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a culturally tailored 1-month walking intervention could increase walking levels and stroke knowledge among racial/ethnic minority seniors with hypertension.
results_summary: The intervention temporarily improved daily walking steps at 1 month but not at 2 months, while significantly increasing stroke preparedness (intention to call 911 for stroke symptoms) with sustained effects. No improvements were observed in other health measures like blood pressure.
population_specificity: Latino, Korean, Chinese, and Black seniors aged 60+ with a history of hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of camera-based mirror visual feedback (camMVF) as an adjunct treatment for stroke patients, comparing its outcomes with conventional therapy and elucidating neural mechanisms.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for walking, but it included the 10-metre walking test as a secondary outcome to assess functional mobility in stroke patients. The abstract does not provide detailed findings on walking improvements.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with motor impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on how different exercise doses (frequency, intensity, time, type) affect cardiorespiratory fitness and walking capacity in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: Higher-intensity training (above 70% of heart rate reserve) improved cardiorespiratory fitness more than lower intensities, while walking capacity improved with longer program durations. Effects of other dose components (frequency, time, type) were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) post-stroke, mostly >6 months after stroke and able to walk independently.
effective_dosage: Intensity >70% of heart rate reserve (specific frequency/time not detailed).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of 12-weeks of walk training with self-selected intensity on lipid profile and anthropometric variables in women with obesity.
results_summary: Walking at self-selected intensity improved biochemical markers (lipid profile) in women with obesity, but no significant changes were observed in anthropometric variables.
population_specificity: Women with obesity (n=48).
effective_dosage: Self-selected walking intensity (amount and frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) versus conventional therapy (CT) in improving gait speed, mobility, balance, fatigue, and quality of life in patients with progressive multiple sclerosis and severe gait disabilities.
results_summary: Both RAGT and CT significantly improved gait speed, but RAGT was not superior to CT. A positive, albeit transitory, effect of rehabilitation was observed in both groups.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive multiple sclerosis (expanded disability status scale score 6.0-7.0) and severe gait disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the late natural history of adults with small, unrepaired atrial septal defects (ASD), including their submaximal exercise capacity (measured via 6-minute walking distance).
results_summary: The study found that patients with small, unrepaired ASD had markedly reduced 6-minute walking distance compared to normative values, regardless of whether the defect was open or closed. This suggests impaired submaximal exercise capacity in this population.
population_specificity: Adult patients (aged 18-65) with small, unrepaired atrial septal defects (ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in muscle activity and gait mechanics when using wedged orthopaedic boots for walking, both immediately and after an accommodation period.
results_summary: Increasing wedges in the boot significantly reduced triceps surae muscle activity, decreased vertical ground reaction force, and increased knee extension power, but did not affect gait speed. No significant changes were observed after the accommodation period.
population_specificity: 12 healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combined strength and aerobic exercise training on functional performance in people with SMA type 3 and identify any adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found no detectable difference in walking distance or cardiopulmonary exercise capacity between the training and usual care groups, with very low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Ambulatory individuals aged 10-48 years with SMA type 3 (Kugelberg-Welander syndrome).
effective_dosage: Strength training as prescribed, but 50% of participants did not achieve the intended aerobic exercise regimen.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of a program combining serial casting, botulinum toxin, splinting, and motor training in managing contractures in patients with severe acquired brain injury.
results_summary: The program significantly improved passive ankle dorsiflexion range, with sustained improvements at Week 2 and Week 8 after casting. Secondary outcomes, including spasticity, ankle dorsiflexor strength, and walking-related measures, also showed positive effects.
population_specificity: 10 patients with severe acquired brain injury (13 ankles).
study_duration: 6 weeks for the control phase, followed by intervention phase (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a training seminar for clinicians could improve their knowledge of gait biomechanics and align resistance exercise prescription to muscle function for walking in adults with neurological conditions.
results_summary: The seminar significantly improved clinician knowledge of gait biomechanics and resistance training, leading to increased prescription of ballistic and conventional resistance training. However, post-seminar support and mentoring provided no additional benefits.
population_specificity: Adults with neurological conditions and clinicians at 12 rehabilitation facilities.
study_duration: Seminar conducted with follow-up assessments immediately after and at three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether core stability training on an unstable support surface improves balance and walking function in individuals with chronic spinal cord injury compared to training on a stable surface.
results_summary: The study found that core stability training on an unstable surface, combined with other exercises, significantly improved stride length, cadence, walking speed, and static balance metrics compared to training on a stable surface after 12 weeks. The unstable support group showed better outcomes in both gait and balance measures.
population_specificity: Chronic spinal cord injury patients (N=29).
effective_dosage: Five times per week for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare pain levels, activity levels, and gait metrics before and after transtibial amputation (TTA) in military service members who had undergone multiple limb preservation attempts.
results_summary: After TTA, patients experienced reduced pain and narcotic use, improved walking endurance, faster FSST times, and better gait metrics (velocity, stride length, cadence, step width). No patients required assistive devices post-amputation.
population_specificity: Young, motivated military service members (8 men, 1 woman; average age 29 ± 6 years) with unilateral lower extremity injuries from trauma (e.g., improvised explosive devices, accidents).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments occurred 8 to 17 months post-amputation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short and long-term impact of a multifactorial intervention, including nurse-guided walks, on physical activity and biochemical parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant increases in daily steps, aerobic steps, distance walked, and metabolic equivalent minutes, along with reduced sedentary time, with effects persisting at 12 months compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients aged 25-70 years with type 2 diabetes mellitus from a primary care health center in Salamanca, Spain.
effective_dosage: Five low-moderate intensity 4 km nurse-guided walks.
study_duration: 12 months (with measurements at baseline, 3 months, and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing standard medical therapy with freeze-dried bilberry improved cardiovascular risk markers and exercise capacity (measured via the 6-minute walk test) in patients after acute myocardial infarction (AMI).
results_summary: The bilberry group showed a significant increase in 6-minute walk test distance (mean difference 38 m) and a reduction in ex vivo oxidized low-density lipoprotein compared to the control group, though no significant differences were found in high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, total cholesterol, or LDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention within 24 hours of AMI.
effective_dosage: 40 g/d of freeze-dried bilberry powder (equivalent to 480 g fresh bilberries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a rare adult case of Dandy-Walker syndrome with syringomyelia and evaluate the effectiveness of surgical treatment.
results_summary: The study found that combined arachnoid adhesiolysis and endoscopic third ventriculostomy effectively relieved symptoms in the patient, with syringomyelia greatly reduced at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: A 33-year-old man with Dandy-Walker syndrome and syringomyelia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and functional differences, including walking capacity recovery, between nursing home and community-dwelling patients after a hip fracture at hospital admission and one year later.
results_summary: Nursing home patients had poorer functional and mental status, higher sarcopenia rates, and lower walking capacity recovery (38.5% vs. 56.2%) at one year compared to community-dwelling patients, though mortality rates did not differ.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (n=509) with hip fractures, including nursing home (22.8%) and community-dwelling (77.2%) individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a national integrated marketing campaign in increasing brisk walking among inactive lower socioeconomic 40-60-year-olds to meet recommended physical activity levels.
results_summary: The campaign achieved around 500,000 app downloads, with evaluations suggesting increased brand and app awareness and behavior change, indicating progress toward recommended physical activity levels.
population_specificity: Inactive lower socioeconomic 40-60-year-olds.
effective_dosage: Brisk walking for bouts of 10 or more minutes per day.
study_duration: Campaigns in the summers of 2017 and 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of botulinum toxin (BoNT) on poststroke upper limb spasticity, including its impact on standing and walking performance.
results_summary: The study found robust evidence for BoNT's effectiveness in reducing resistance to passive movement and improving self-care ability, but no evidence was found for its effect on arm and hand use after intervention. Walking performance was categorized as a clinical goal, but specific results for walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with a history of stroke (2718 participants across 40 trials).
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed at 4-8 weeks and 12 weeks after injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of the direct anterior approach (DAA) versus the lateral approach (LA) for total hip arthroplasty (THA) patients, focusing on pain relief, blood loss, and walking metrics.
results_summary: The DAA was associated with reduced pain (VAS) and blood loss, as well as improved walking velocity, stride length, and step length compared to the LA. No significant differences were found in Harris hip score, operation time, transfusion rate, hospital stay, or complications.
population_specificity: Total hip arthroplasty (THA) patients (475 participants across 5 RCTs).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical approaches compared, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a home-based aerobic and resistance exercise program on physical functioning and health-related quality of life in peritoneal dialysis (PD) patients.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in walking distance, multiple HRQOL subscales, and serum albumin levels compared to the usual care group, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Peritoneal dialysis (PD) patients
effective_dosage: Aerobic exercise thrice weekly and resistance training twice weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 4-week postoperative rehabilitation program in Nursing Care Facilities improved quality of life and mobility compared to usual care in older adults recovering from hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: At 4 weeks, the treatment group showed better mobility and higher survival rates, but no difference in quality of life. At 12 months, the treatment group had slightly better quality of life, but other outcomes did not differ.
population_specificity: People aged 70+ recovering from hip fracture surgery who were walking prior to the fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of supervised exercise therapy (SET) versus revascularization in preventing additional invasive interventions for patients with intermittent claudication, based on lesion location.
results_summary: SET was effective in preventing invasive treatment for patients with mainly outflow lesions, with 82% freedom from intervention at 2 years. Primary revascularization for inflow lesions had higher secondary intervention rates (65% freedom at 2 years), despite high target lesion revascularization success.
population_specificity: 474 patients with intermittent claudication, categorized by lesion location (aortoiliac/common femoral artery vs. distal disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether structured home exercise programmes improve walking performance and physical activity in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) compared to controls not receiving an exercise programme.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that structured home exercise programmes significantly improved maximum walking distance, intermittent claudication onset distance, 6-minute walking test distance, and physical activity levels in PAD patients. The improvements were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
study_duration: 2 to 24 months (only one trial beyond 12 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if unsupervised home exercise (including walking) was noninferior to formal outpatient physical therapy (PT) for recovery after primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and whether a web-based platform offered advantages over a printed manual.
results_summary: Unsupervised home exercise was noninferior to outpatient PT in restoring knee flexion and functional outcomes (KOOS scores, return to daily activities). No significant differences were found between web-based and printed manual approaches.
population_specificity: Adults >18 years undergoing primary, unilateral TKA, excluding those with preoperative knee flexion <90° or planned hip/contralateral knee surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise protocols described but not quantified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of an early childhood development program integrated into government health clinics on child cognition, language, motor development, growth, and behavior, but the study does not focus on Walking.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention improved children's cognition, language, motor skills, and behavior but had no significant effect on growth. The abstract does not report findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Underweight children aged 5-24 months living within a 30-minute walk of community clinics in Narsingdi district, Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study did not evaluate Walking).

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether combining exercise with breaks in sitting has an additive effect on reducing blood pressure in older overweight/obese adults, and examined sex differences and plasma catecholamines as potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that both exercise and breaks in prolonged sitting reduced blood pressure, with potential additive effects when combined. Sex differences and changes in plasma catecholamines were also examined as underlying mechanisms.
population_specificity: Sedentary older adults (n=67; 67±7 years; BMI 31.2±4.1 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of e- and mHealth interventions in promoting physical activity, including walking, among African American and Hispanic women.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of the interventions reported significant improvements in at least one physical activity outcome, though most studies were pilot-scale and only two were full-scale randomized controlled trials. The findings suggest preliminary support for e- and mHealth interventions in promoting physical activity in these populations.
population_specificity: African American and Hispanic women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of supervised exercise therapy (SET) on modifiable cardiovascular risk factors in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: SET significantly improved systolic blood pressure (short-term decrease of 4 mm Hg) and cholesterol levels (midterm decrease in total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol). The findings support SET for both walking distance improvement and cardiovascular risk factor modification.
population_specificity: Symptomatic intermittent claudication (IC) patients.
study_duration: Short-term (6 weeks-3 months) and midterm (6-12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of split-belt treadmill (SBT) walking in modulating gait asymmetry in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) and compare their adaptation to healthy controls.
results_summary: People with mild to moderate PD adapted similarly to healthy controls in gait variability and bilateral coordination during SBT walking, but those with freezing of gait (FOG) showed impaired perception of belt speed differences and slower adaptation. SBT was beneficial for modulating gait asymmetry in some but not all individuals with PD.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (n=118, including 44 with freezing of gait) and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of high-dose n-3 PUFA supplementation on inflammation, endothelial function, and walking ability in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased the omega-3 index and markers of specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs) in PAD patients, but clinical improvements in walking ability were not conclusively demonstrated.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate walking as a key functional mobility activity in older persons and its relevance as a clinical and research outcome in geriatric rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study highlights that quantitative gait analysis can detail walking performance, including parameters like speed, symmetry, regularity, coordination, balance, and foot movement, which are useful for clinical and research purposes.
population_specificity: Older persons undergoing geriatric rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review neuroimaging techniques and pharmacological treatments for diagnosing and managing Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH), which includes walking difficulties as a hallmark symptom.
results_summary: The study highlighted the importance of neuroimaging for monitoring NPH and discussed pharmacological agents as non-invasive alternatives to surgical interventions, but did not specifically evaluate walking outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dose-response relationship between the frequency of breaks in sedentary time (walking) and glucose control in adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that interrupting sedentary time every 15 minutes (Condition 3) resulted in better glucose control compared to longer intervals (Conditions 1 and 2). There was a potential dose-response relationship between the frequency of breaks and glucose levels.
population_specificity: Twelve adults with type 2 diabetes (age 60±11 years, BMI 30.2±4.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Breaks in sedentary time every 15 minutes (Condition 3), 30 minutes (Condition 2), and continuous sitting (Condition 1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of an individualized exercise training program, including Nordic walking, on mobility and physical fitness in patients with non-small cell lung cancer during chemotherapy.
results_summary: The exercise training group showed significant improvements in 6-minute walk distance, physical performance tests (Up and Go Test, chair stand, arm curl), and spirometry values (FEV1, FVC, FEV1/FVC) compared to the control group, with no adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with non-small cell lung cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 4-week in-hospital exercise training program, including warm-up, respiratory muscle exercise, cycle ergometer or treadmill training, and Nordic walking, performed in 2-week cycles interspersed with chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether motivational interviewing (MI) was more effective than Patient-Centered Assessment and Counseling for Exercise (PACE) or a control group in improving walking distance among African American patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvements in walking distance for MI or PACE compared to the control group at 6 or 12 months, though PACE showed a significant increase over MI at 12 months. The results did not support the use of MI to improve walking performance in this population.
population_specificity: African American patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), mean age 64.2 years, 74% female.
effective_dosage: Counseling interventions (MI and PACE) were delivered biweekly for 3 months and monthly for 3 months, followed by a 6-month maintenance phase with limited contact.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured walking intervention could reduce obesity-related metrics (BMI, waist circumference, blood pressure) in women in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: The walking intervention group showed significant improvements in BMI, waist circumference, and blood pressure compared to the control group, which experienced increases in these metrics. The study suggests that walking can be an effective intervention for obesity-related outcomes.
population_specificity: 115 women employed at the University of Venda, Limpopo province, South Africa.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes, 3 days per week on treadmills.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of visual feedback balance training combined with conventional gait rehabilitation in improving balance and gait function in CSVD patients.
results_summary: The study found that visual feedback balance training combined with conventional rehabilitation significantly improved balance and gait function more than conventional rehabilitation alone, as measured by the Tinetti Scale and Pro-Kin system. Greater improvements were observed in the observation group, and balance function was better with eyes open than closed.
population_specificity: Fifty-six patients with Cerebral Small Vessel Disease (CSVD).
effective_dosage: Training was performed twice a day for 20 minutes each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of decompressive spinal surgery versus a placebo surgical intervention for improving function and walking capacity in patients with symptomatic lumbar spinal stenosis.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a blinded, placebo-controlled trial design but does not report results as the trial is still in progress (pre-results). Outcomes will assess function, walking capacity, pain, disability, and quality of life at multiple follow-up intervals.
population_specificity: Older adults with symptomatic central lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed up to 24 months post-randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare disease progression and tolerance to pirfenidone in familial pulmonary fibrosis (FPF) and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) patients, including their performance in the 6-minute walking test.
results_summary: FPF patients showed a significantly greater decline in walked distance during the 6-minute walking test compared to IPF patients at 24 months. No significant differences in drug tolerance or side effects were observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with familial pulmonary fibrosis (FPF) and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether early surgical treatment of femur fractures reduced the time to ambulation (walking) in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that 51% of patients were treated within 48 hours, but the time from surgery to physiotherapy start was 2 days, and time to first walking day was 6 days—longer than most published studies. The authors suggest revising the performance index to focus on return to walking within 96 hours.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (aged 65+) with proximal femoral fractures admitted to two level I trauma centers in Italy.
study_duration: Retrospective analysis of patients admitted in 2017; follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare in vivo knee kinematics and clinical outcomes between fixed- and mobile-bearing total knee arthroplasty (TKA) patients during walking and other activities at 1- and 2-year follow-ups.
results_summary: The study evaluated knee kinematics and patient-reported outcomes (KOS-ADLS and pain VAS) in TKA patients, but the abstract does not specify the comparative results between fixed- and mobile-bearing groups.
population_specificity: 64 patients randomized into fixed- and mobile-bearing TKA groups (32 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of telemedicine tools, including portable sensors for monitoring walking and physical activity, in improving the management and adherence of persons with haemophilia (PWH).
results_summary: Portable sensors were found to help improve lifestyle and monitor physical activity, including daily walking steps, in PWH. The study suggests telemedicine tools, including walking monitoring, may enhance disease management, particularly for patients distant from specialized centers.
population_specificity: Persons with haemophilia (PWH)

study_goal: To determine the effects of elastic band exercise on frailty states, grip strength, and walking speed in pre-frail elderly people.
results_summary: The elastic band group showed significant improvements in frailty states, grip strength (female), and walking speed after 4-week and 8-week interventions, with better effects observed after 8 weeks.
population_specificity: Pre-frail elderly people (70 participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if individualized interdisciplinary interventions using gait analysis improved gait and function more effectively than usual care in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant or clinically relevant differences in gait, walking, or patient-reported outcomes between the intervention group (using gait analysis) and the control group (usual care). Compliance with recommended interventions was low, and no advantages were identified for the gait analysis group.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I or II), aged 5-9 years, who were independently walking and not expected to need surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of noninvasive brain stimulation (NIBS) combined with other therapies on gait speed after stroke.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that NIBS combined with other therapies was effective for improving gait speed (MD 0.09 m/s) after stroke, with moderate-quality evidence supporting the conclusion.
population_specificity: Stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of oxidative damage in frailty and whether interventions like exercise (including walking) could delay frailty onset.
results_summary: The study found that exercise programs, including walking, do not promote longevity but effectively delay the onset of frailty and its progression to disability. Oxidative damage correlates with unsuccessful ageing rather than chronological ageing, and interventions targeting oxidative stress can prevent frailty.
population_specificity: Older adults (geriatric population)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different daily physical activity frequencies (short bouts vs. long bouts) on weight loss and metabolic outcomes in women with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity divided into two shorter bouts per day resulted in greater weight loss and BMI reduction compared to a single long bout, with no significant differences in carbohydrate or lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Adult women with a BMI of 27-35 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Not specified (same daily volume of physical activity, but different frequencies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Kinesio tape (KT) on lower limb muscle activation patterns in children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD) during walking.
results_summary: The study found that KT application increased gastrocnemius medialis muscle activation during the stance phase of gait in children with DCD. The KT group showed higher peak activation compared to the control group, suggesting KT may facilitate muscle contraction during walking.
population_specificity: Children with developmental coordination disorder (DCD), mean age ~8 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (KT applied to quadriceps and gastrocnemius muscles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of moderate-intensity morning exercise with and without light-intensity walking breaks on cerebral blood velocity in older adults over an 8-hour period.
results_summary: The study found that a morning bout of moderate-intensity exercise, combined with light-intensity walking breaks, influenced cerebral blood velocity in overweight/obese older adults, suggesting potential benefits for maintaining brain health with aging.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese older adults (n=12, age 70±7 years, BMI 30.4±4.3 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if trimetazidine, an inhibitor of fatty acid metabolism, could improve exercise capacity (including walking distance) in patients with symptomatic nonobstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
results_summary: Trimetazidine therapy did not improve exercise capacity; patients in the trimetazidine group walked 38.4 meters less than the placebo group after 3 months, and peak oxygen consumption was lower in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients (NYHA class ≥2) aged 24-74 years with nonobstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and reduced exercise capacity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review literature on gait speed measurement in older adults and propose a standardized protocol for clinical and community settings.
results_summary: The study identified variability in gait speed measurement protocols across 50 articles, with differences in timing devices, walking distances, and other essential elements. A standardized protocol was proposed to address this inconsistency.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dynamic hallux valgus splint could improve pain and structural outcomes in patients with symptomatic hallux valgus.
results_summary: The study found that wearing a dynamic hallux valgus splint provided significant pain relief during walking and running, as well as at rest, but did not improve hallux valgus angle or other radiological parameters.
population_specificity: 70 patients with hallux valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and clinical effects of overground exoskeleton-assisted gait training (OEAGT) in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical and gait outcomes, with 69.57% of patients able to walk at baseline and 17.39% regaining ambulation after training. Ambulant patients showed statistical improvements in walking speed (10MWT) and endurance (6mWT), and all subjects perceived OEAGT positively.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients (46 subjects, 56.84±14.29 years, 27 male, 29 ischemic, 24 left hemiparesis).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but sessions were conducted over a training period (likely several weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the phenotypic and genetic spectrum of AP1S2 mutations, including their association with neurodevelopmental disorders such as delayed walking.
results_summary: The study identified a new AP1S2 mutation and summarized clinical manifestations in 59 patients, noting that mutations are linked to neurodevelopmental issues, including delayed walking and abnormal gait.
population_specificity: A Chinese family with AP1S2 variation and a review of 59 patients with AP1S2 mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and acceptability of an mHealth-mediated exercise program (walking with a pedometer and planned exercise) compared to an active control (walking with a pedometer only) in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Both groups increased daily steps and moderate-intensity minutes, with no significant between-group differences. The mHealth app showed clinically meaningful benefits in less active participants, particularly in mobility scores.
population_specificity: 51 participants with mild-to-moderately severe idiopathic Parkinson's disease (Hoehn and Yahr stages 1-3).
effective_dosage: Not specified (walking with a pedometer and planned exercise supported by an mHealth app vs. walking with a pedometer only).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the advantages and limitations of gait evaluation methods in persons with multiple sclerosis (PMS) and propose a minimum set of measurements for clinical and research use.
results_summary: The study found that different gait evaluation methods (e.g., timed 25-foot walk, Timed Up and Go test, 6-minute walk test) have varying metrological characteristics, particularly in reproducibility, and proposed a standardized set of measurements for assessing gait in PMS.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physicians' diagnostic values of signs and symptoms for differentiating hip osteoarthritis (OA) from lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and assess their clinical utility.
results_summary: The study found substantial symptom overlap between hip OA and LSS, with only 11 of 32 physician-valued symptoms useful for differentiation. Physical examination items, particularly gait and hip maneuvers, were more effective in distinguishing the two conditions.
population_specificity: Seventy-seven hip OA and 79 LSS patients recruited from hip and spine specialty practices.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the time course, sustainability, and transferability of gait adaptations to treadmill training with and without additional postural perturbations in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Treadmill gait variability reduced linearly over 8 weeks in both groups, but only the perturbation treadmill training (PTT) group showed significant improvements in other gait parameters. Transfer to overground walking was limited, though PTT tended to enhance efficacy and sustainability of certain gait measures.
population_specificity: 38 Parkinson's disease patients (Hoehn & Yahr stages 1-3.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) stiffness on walking mechanics.
results_summary: Greater AFO stiffness generally reduced peak ankle plantarflexion, dorsiflexion, and total range of motion, while increasing dorsiflexion at initial contact. Knee kinematics showed mixed effects, but stiffness did not significantly affect hip kinetics, muscle activity, metabolic cost, or spatiotemporal parameters.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, post-stroke patients, and those with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 24-week walking program could improve biochemical parameters (FBS and lipid profile) in elderly women.
results_summary: The walking program significantly improved FBS, total cholesterol, triglyceride, HDL cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol levels compared to the control group (p < 0.001). The intervention was effective in reducing chronic vascular disease risk factors.
population_specificity: Elderly women (mean age 68.33 ± 4.55 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of different levels of blood flow restriction (BFR) on energy expenditure and subjective discomfort during walking.
results_summary: The study found that energy expenditure significantly increased with BFR levels of 50%, 80%, and 100%, with the strongest increase up to 50% BFR. Discomfort also increased with higher BFR levels, suggesting that BFR above 50% may not be necessary for optimal energy expenditure with moderate discomfort.
population_specificity: 24 young men
effective_dosage: 0%, 50%, 80%, and 100% BFR applied once a week
study_duration: 14 minutes per session, with 7-day intervals between evaluations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of exercise interventions, including walking, on preventing falls in older people living in the community.
results_summary: The study found that walking programmes' effects on the rate of falls and the number of people experiencing falls were uncertain, with no clear evidence of efficacy compared to other exercise types like balance and functional exercises or Tai Chi.
population_specificity: Older people aged 60+ years living in the community, with an average age of 76 and 77% women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to re-evaluate the efficacy, safety, and feasibility of aerobic physical exercise (primarily walking) for adults with haematological malignancies, updating a previous review.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of a difference in mortality between exercise and control groups, but exercise might improve fatigue and depression. Evidence for quality of life, physical functioning, and anxiety was inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults with haematological malignancies, including acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, acute myeloid leukaemia, malignant lymphoma, and multiple myeloma, some undergoing stem cell transplantation.
effective_dosage: Various walking intervention programmes with different duration and intensity levels (specifics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if inflammatory markers (IL-6 and TNF-α) were related to post-operative mortality and walking capability in hip fracture patients.
results_summary: The study found significantly higher IL-6 levels post-surgery but no statistical link between these markers and mortality or walking capability. The overall death rate was 35% within 2 years.
population_specificity: 40 Turkish hip fracture patients compared to 40 age-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare temporal changes in ESC acute myocardial infarction (AMI) quality indicator attainment between the UK and Israel.
results_summary: The study found higher rates of coronary angiography and percutaneous coronary intervention in Israel compared to the UK, with composite QI performance increasing more in the UK. Mortality rates at 30 days declined in both countries, with lower rates in Israel in 2013.
population_specificity: Patients with acute myocardial infarction in the UK (n=17,068) and Israel (n=5,647).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a multilevel intervention (individual, interpersonal, and community-level) to increase physical activity, specifically walking, among rural residents.
results_summary: The study proposed a multilevel intervention involving SMS text messages, walking groups, and community events to increase moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, measured via self-reports and accelerometry. Results were not yet available as the study was ongoing, but the approach aimed to enhance scalability for rural populations.
population_specificity: Adult residents of 6 rural communities in the United States (n=600 intervention, n=600 control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the health effects of reablement, including improvements in walking and physical performance, in home-dwelling adults with functional decline.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking (measured by SPPB subscales) and other physical performance metrics after 6 and 12 months in the reablement group compared to the control group. These effects were most pronounced at 6 months but diminished slightly by 12 months.
population_specificity: Home-dwelling adults with functional decline in Norway.
effective_dosage: 4-10 week reablement program (specific walking dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 4-10 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at 10 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nordic walking (with poles) provided greater improvements in functional mobility, quality of life, and postural balance compared to free walking (without poles) in untrained elderly individuals.
results_summary: Both Nordic walking and free walking groups showed improvements in self-selected walking speed, locomotor rehabilitation index, quality of life, static balance, and dynamic variability, but Nordic walking did not result in significantly greater improvements than free walking for most outcomes.
population_specificity: Untrained older adults (Nordic walking group: 64.6±4.1 years; free walking group: 68.6±3.9 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore osteoarthritis (OA) as a systemic organ disease, examining its associations with metabolic components, joint deformity, and developmental factors like age of first walking.
results_summary: The study found associations between OA and metabolic conditions (hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, blood glucose), identified hip shape as an imaging biomarker linked to early walking age and obesity, and suggested tissue regeneration approaches may have limited benefit.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of osteoarthritis and related factors)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between frailty (including slow walking speed as a criterion) and measures of adiposity (%BF and WC) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that frail individuals had significantly higher %BF and WC compared to robust individuals, with pre-frail and frail individuals showing progressively greater WC. Walking speed (as part of frailty criteria) was indirectly associated with adiposity measures.
population_specificity: Older community-dwelling adults aged ≥60 years from the NHANES 1999-2004 survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether virtual reality gait training improves participation in daily life for community-living stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study examined the effects of VR gait training on participation, functional mobility, walking ability, and other secondary outcomes, but the abstract does not report specific results.
population_specificity: Fifty people between 2 weeks and 6 months post-stroke with walking constraints.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 30-minute VR or non-VR gait training.

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare impact loading parameters measured by shoe-mounted and tibia sensors before and after walking or running retraining.
results_summary: The study found that real-time biofeedback gait retraining can effectively lower impact loading during gait, with comparisons made between shoe-mounted and tibia sensors.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of continuous versus intermittent walking programs on body composition, aerobic fitness, and physical activity in sedentary office employees.
results_summary: Both walking programs similarly reduced fat mass and fat percentage, but intermittent walking also increased lean mass and fat-free mass. No significant changes were observed in sedentary behavior or VO2 max for any group.
population_specificity: Sedentary office employees (aged 42–48, BMI 27.5–30.6 kg/m²).
