effective_dosage: Not specified (two walking programs: multiple bouts and continuous).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of the CPWalker-based rehabilitation intervention on gait parameters and symmetry in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that seven out of eighteen gait parameters showed statistically significant improvements when using the CPWalker, indicating potential benefits for muscular strength and gait patterns in children with CP. These changes suggest the platform's effectiveness in rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (eight subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the SymptoMScreen PRO and its domains against performance-based and clinician-assessed measures in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found strong correlations between mobility scores (from SymptoMScreen) and walking speed (r = 0.63), indicating that the SymptoMScreen effectively assesses walking-related symptoms in MS patients. The overall SymptoMScreen also showed high reliability (ICC: 0.88; Cronbach's alpha: 0.93).
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (predominantly female, average age 47.6 years, average disease duration 13.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of Köhler disease in children, including the effectiveness of immobilization with a short leg walking cast.
results_summary: The study found that long-term outcomes for Köhler disease are favorable regardless of treatment type, but a short period of immobilization with a short leg walking cast may reduce symptom duration. Radiographs showed sclerosis, flattening, and fragmentation of the navicular.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-10 years, predominantly boys.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multicomponent intervention (including physical, cognitive, and social activities) could improve cognitive function and maintain physical activity in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The intervention improved spatial working memory and maintained physical activity levels (step count and moderate-to-vigorous activity) compared to the control group, which saw declines in physical activity. No significant differences were found in other cognitive or secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: Japanese older adults (n=83) with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: 90-minute sessions (physical, cognitive, or social activities) twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of total body resistance exercise suspension training on mobility, proprioception, and muscle strength of the knee in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The training group showed significant improvements in mobility, knee proprioception (nondominant leg at 60° flexion), and isometric strength of knee flexor and extensor muscles compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thirty-four women with relapsing-remitting MS (mean age 36.44 years, Expanded Disability Status Scale 2.35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare changes in physical activity levels using self-reported (IPAQ) and objective (accelerometry) measures in response to pedometer-based walking interventions.
results_summary: Both intervention groups significantly increased accelerometer-measured moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) compared to control, while self-reported walking (IPAQ-Walk) also increased but with less precision. Self-reported MVPA (IPAQ-MVPA) showed non-significant decreases.
population_specificity: 1023 participants in the PACE-UP trial, with 655 providing complete data at baseline and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of electromyographic biofeedback-assisted exercise versus sham biofeedback on clinical and functional outcomes in hemiplegic patients.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in range of motion, muscle strength, Barthel Index, and 10-m walking time, suggesting exercise (with or without biofeedback) is effective for hemiplegic patients. The study could not conclusively determine additional benefits from biofeedback.
population_specificity: Thirty-four hemiplegic patients (17 per group).
effective_dosage: Exercise interventions and ambulation training 5 days a week.
study_duration: 2 weeks, with follow-ups at 1 and 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week high-intensity Pulmonary Rehabilitation program, including walking, on functional and quality-of-life measures in patients with Interstitial Lung Disease.
results_summary: The 12-week PR program led to significant improvements in the 6-minute walking distance test, modified Borg Scale, mMRC scores, and health status measures in the active group, though lung function measures did not improve.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with Interstitial Lung Disease (120 participants, split into active and inactive groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (high-intensity PR program, including walking).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the minimal detectable difference (MDD) in endurance shuttle walk test (ESWT) performance following supervised ground-based walking training in people with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that the MDD for ESWT performance differed between anchor- and distribution-based approaches, and large variation in test performance suggests caution in using MDD to interpret individual changes.
population_specificity: People with moderate-to-severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), aged 70 ± 8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether race affects the response to medical therapy (specifically granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor [GM-CSF] and supervised treadmill exercise) in people with peripheral artery disease (PAD), as measured by changes in 6-minute walk distance.
results_summary: GM-CSF improved 6-minute walk distance in white PAD participants at 26 weeks but had no effect in black participants. Exercise improved walking distance in both black and white participants without racial interaction.
population_specificity: 210 PAD participants (67% black, 30% white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait differences (foot loading and temporal variables) between two surgical approaches (ELA and sinus tarsi) for treating calcaneal fractures.
results_summary: The ELA showed significant differences in foot loading and temporal variables between operated and uninjured limbs, while the sinus tarsi approach showed minimal differences. The sinus tarsi approach resulted in nearly normal gait patterns post-surgery.
population_specificity: 22 patients with intra-articular calcaneal fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the systematic effects of elastic abdominal belts on trunk musculature, pain intensity, and functional impairment in individuals with acute lumbar back pain during walking.
results_summary: The belt group showed slightly better pain reduction and functional improvement compared to controls, with reduced abdominal muscle activation but no significant change in back muscle activity, suggesting a temporary alteration in trunk muscle coordination rather than uniform deconditioning.
population_specificity: 36 persons with acute lumbar back pain (duration ≤1 week).
effective_dosage: Not specified (belt usage details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare walking gait biomechanics between individuals with knee osteoarthritis who responded to a quadriceps strengthening intervention and those who did not.
results_summary: Responders showed greater knee flexion angle (KFA) in the first half of stance at baseline and greater knee extension in the second half of stance post-intervention compared to non-responders. No significant changes were observed in vertical ground reaction force (vGRF) or internal knee extension moment (KEM).
population_specificity: 53 participants with radiographic knee osteoarthritis (47% female, mean age 62.3 ± 7.1 years, BMI 28.5 ± 3.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a walking intervention (prehabilitation) for rectal cancer patients undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NACRT) to inform a larger clinical trial.
results_summary: The walking intervention showed promising but non-significant reductions in the decline of daily walking compared to standard care. High patient satisfaction and adherence were reported, supporting the feasibility of a larger trial.
population_specificity: Rectal cancer patients (mean age 65.9 years, 65% male) scheduled for NACRT and surgery.
effective_dosage: Telephone-guided walking program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of different exercise modalities (static stretching, balance task, concentric contractions, and control) on ankle force sense during functional activities like walking.
results_summary: The study found that static stretching significantly reduced ankle force sense, while concentric contractions and balance tasks did not show significant differences. Static stretching led to a 31.4% increase in error scores compared to other conditions.
population_specificity: Seventeen subjects (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included static stretching, balance task, concentric contractions, and control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and psychological effects of brief walks in forests compared to city areas on young women.
results_summary: Walking in forests significantly increased parasympathetic nervous activity and reduced sympathetic nervous activity, heart rate, and negative psychological states while improving relaxation and mood. The subjective evaluations aligned with the physiological responses, indicating relaxation effects.
population_specificity: Young women (mean age: 21.0 ± 1.3 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ischemic conditioning (IC) could improve gait speed and paretic leg muscle function in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found that IC training significantly increased self-selected walking speed and improved paretic muscle fatigue resistance in stroke survivors, while the sham group showed no significant changes. Maximum voluntary contractions remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors
effective_dosage: 5-min bouts of ischemia, repeated five times, every other day for 2 weeks (7 total sessions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand footwear characteristics, experiences, and factors influencing footwear choice in people with gout.
results_summary: The study found that people with gout need comfortable shoes with specific features like a wide opening, pliable materials, and adjustable straps. Barriers included difficulty finding shoes that were wide enough, suitable for work, and aesthetically pleasing.
population_specificity: People with gout who visited a gout education website.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of three nonsurgical interventions (medical care, group exercise, and manual therapy/individualized exercise) for improving symptoms, physical function, and walking capacity in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Manual therapy/individualized exercise showed greater short-term improvement in symptoms, physical function, and walking capacity compared to medical care or group exercise, though all interventions improved long-term walking capacity. At 6 months, there were no significant differences between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients older than 60 years with lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and clinical symptoms such as neurogenic claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation fidelity, reach, and dose of two physical activity programs (100 Mile Club walking/running and CHALK/Just Move classroom breaks) in low-income elementary schools to enhance children's in-school physical activity.
results_summary: The 100 Mile Club walking/running program delivered a higher dose of physical activity per week (34.9 min) and per session (13.6 min) compared to CHALK/Just Move (19.7 min per week, 2.7 min per session). Both programs were well-received, but implementation varied, with some schools not adhering fully over the two-year period.
population_specificity: Children in 13 diverse, low-income Massachusetts elementary schools.
effective_dosage: 100 Mile Club: 34.9 min per week; CHALK/Just Move: 19.7 min per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify long-term clinical outcomes and prognostic factors in patients with SLE-associated PAH, including the role of 6-minute walking distance as a potential marker.
results_summary: The study found that a 6-minute walking distance >380 m was associated with better outcomes in SLE-associated PAH patients, with 1-, 3-, and 5-year survival rates of 92.1%, 84.8%, and 72.9%, respectively. Treatment goal achievement rates also improved over time.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) confirmed by right heart catheterisation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combined pulmonary exercise program (incorporating traditional Chinese exercises) and resistance exercise on COPD patients, compared to usual care or standalone exercise interventions.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the outcomes of the intervention, as it describes the study design and methodology rather than findings.
population_specificity: COPD patients aged 40-80 years, with stable medical treatment and no regular exercise in the last 6 months.
effective_dosage: Pulmonary exercise group: 60 min twice daily, 7 days/week; resistance exercise group: 60 min once daily, 3 days/week; combined group: 60 min of prescribed pulmonary and resistance exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Qishenyiqi dripping pill in improving ventricular remodeling and function in chronic heart failure (CHF) patients.
results_summary: Qishenyiqi combined with routine treatment significantly improved NYHA functional classification, left ventricular ejection fraction, cardiac index, and 6-minute walking test while reducing brain natriuretic peptide and left ventricular dimensions, with no obvious side effects compared to routine therapy alone.
population_specificity: Chronic heart failure (CHF) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Pilates on physical function, fatigue, quality of life, and other outcomes in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Pilates showed significant improvements in physical function, fatigue, balance confidence, and walking ability in people with MS, but was not more effective than other therapies for functional mobility, cardiorespiratory fitness, fatigue, and quality of life. Depression was unaffected by Pilates.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the safety and effectiveness of botulinum toxin type A (BoNT-A), particularly higher doses, for treating lower limb spasticity after stroke.
results_summary: The study found that BoNT-A is safe and effective in reducing lower limb spasticity post-stroke, with higher doses showing greater reduction in severe spasticity. A combined approach of surgery and BoNT-A may be beneficial for ankle plantar-flexor spasticity, though motor function improvement remains controversial.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with lower limb spasticity, particularly those with ankle plantar-flexor muscle involvement.
effective_dosage: Higher doses of BoNT-A (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of catheter ablation compared to medical treatment for managing atrial fibrillation in patients with heart failure and reduced ejection fraction.
results_summary: The study found that catheter ablation was more effective than optimal medical therapy in reducing all-cause mortality, hospitalization for heart failure, and improving left ventricular ejection fraction, as well as functional outcomes like the Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire and 6-minute walking distance.
population_specificity: Patients with atrial fibrillation and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether three-dimensional balance training with visual feedback improves balance and walking ability in subacute stroke patients compared to conventional training.
results_summary: The study found that three-dimensional balance training with visual feedback significantly improved balance (Berg balance scale), gait parameters (speed, cadence, step length, double-limb support), and activity-specific balance confidence compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of a standardized pulmonary rehabilitation program conducted in a community-based setting on exercise capacity (measured by 6MWD) and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in patients with COPD.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvements in both exercise capacity (mean change in 6MWD of 45 m) and HRQoL after the rehabilitation program. The effects were comparable to those seen in hospital-based PR.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe COPD attending community-based pulmonary rehabilitation in Denmark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between BMI and the severity of acute ankle injuries (sprains or fractures) caused by falls while walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between BMI and ankle fracture severity, with ankle sprains being more common in normal BMI patients. Age was a key determinant, as patients over 30 were 20% more likely to suffer fractures.
population_specificity: Patients ≥18 years with acute traumatic ankle injuries from falls while walking, treated at a university hospital emergency room.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of excessive walking as a potential trigger for idiopathic hip chondrolysis in a susceptible individual and explore treatment outcomes.
results_summary: Excessive walking was identified as an apparent trigger for idiopathic hip chondrolysis in an HLA-B27 positive adolescent. Initial treatments failed, but TNF-inhibitor therapy improved range of motion, though stiffness persisted.
population_specificity: 15-year-old HLA-B27 positive male with idiopathic hip chondrolysis.
study_duration: Not specified (brief improvement noted for 3 months post-surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association of physical activity (including walking) with sleep quality and cognitive function in elderly patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: Locomotive activity (including walking) correlated with improved sleep latency and cognitive function, while household activity did not. Exercise tolerance (measured by 6-min walking distance) was an independent predictor of cognitive function, though this relationship disappeared when excluding patients with heart failure.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 74±7.4 years) with cardiovascular disease in phase III cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (physical activity assessed via steps/day: 5506.8±3743.6).
study_duration: Physical activity was assessed over 7 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Ankle Osteoarthritis Scale instrument for measuring pain and dysfunction in patients with end-stage ankle arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that the Ankle Osteoarthritis Scale effectively measured pain and dysfunction, with item 10 ("walking around the house") better fitting the pain domain. Differential item functioning for sex, age, and surgery type was negligible.
population_specificity: 88 patients scheduled for ankle arthrodesis or total ankle replacement in Vancouver, Canada.
study_duration: Data collected between September 2014 and August 2017 (specific intervention duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between pain severity, pain variability, and physical activity (including walking) in older adults with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Greater pain severity was associated with less physical activity in women, while greater pain variability was linked to more physical activity in men. Walking was one of the activities assessed, but the study did not isolate its effects from other physical activities.
population_specificity: Older adults (65-85 years) with osteoarthritis, predominantly women (70%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects and feasibility of non-linear periodized resistance training versus traditional non-periodized resistance training on limb-muscle strength and endurance in people with COPD.
results_summary: The study found that periodized resistance training could potentially improve limb-muscle strength and endurance more effectively than traditional non-periodized training, with implications for enhancing walking capacity and functional performance in COPD patients.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a supervised walking program in women with primary Sjögren's syndrome (pSS).
results_summary: The supervised walking program improved cardiorespiratory fitness, exercise tolerance, fatigue, and patient perception of improvement in pSS patients, with no reported adverse effects.
population_specificity: Sedentary women with primary Sjögren's syndrome (pSS).
effective_dosage: Supervised walking three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a wearable visual aid device in improving walking ability for retinitis pigmentosa (RP) patients with night blindness.
results_summary: The device significantly improved binocular visual acuity in the dark, reduced the number of walking errors, and shortened travel time for RP patients.
population_specificity: Twenty-eight retinitis pigmentosa (RP) patients with night blindness.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of practice variability combined with task-oriented electromyographic biofeedback (EMGBFB) on strength and balance in people with chronic stroke.
results_summary: TA strength increased significantly in both the constant and variable EMGBFB groups, while balance improved only in the variable group. All participants showed improvements in walking speed, TUGT, and 6MWT.
population_specificity: People with chronic stroke

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the predictive value of baseline and changing 6-minute walk test (6MWT) distance for morbidity and mortality in heart failure (HF) patients.
results_summary: The study found that both baseline 6MWT distance and a decline in walking distance were associated with worse prognosis in HF patients, but these measures did not improve prognostic models. Additionally, 6MWT distance was not affected by treatment up-titration, suggesting limited utility for assessing pharmacologic treatment benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF) from the BIOSTAT-CHF cohort.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 21 months, with 6MWT performed at baseline and 9 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term effects of a chronic pain self-management course versus low-impact outdoor physical activity (including walking) on patient activation and secondary outcomes in individuals with chronic pain.
results_summary: After twelve months, no significant differences were found between the self-management course and the walking-based physical activity group for primary or secondary outcomes. Both groups showed improvements in pain, self-rated health, and physical function (30-s Chair to Stand Test).
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain in a public primary care setting.
effective_dosage: One-hour weekly sessions of walking and simple strength exercises for six weeks.
study_duration: Six weeks (with follow-up at twelve months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a decline in activities of daily living (ADL), specifically walking ability, correlates with hospitalization and mortality in heart failure (HF) patients.
results_summary: Decline in ADL, including reduced walking ability, was associated with higher risks of hospitalization for HF and mortality. Multivariate analysis confirmed decline ADL as an independent risk factor for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients from a community-based cohort (Kitakawachi Clinical Background and Outcome of Heart Failure Registry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between serum CT-proAVP levels and self-reported anxiety in patients with cardiovascular risk factors, not specifically related to Walking.
results_summary: The study found an inverse correlation between CT-proAVP and anxiety in men with cardiovascular risk factors, but not in women. The association was independent of physical impairment severity.
population_specificity: 1463 participants with cardiovascular risk factors (mean age 66.7 years, 51.3% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term functional evolution, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), in lung transplant recipients with and without Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome (BOS).
results_summary: The study found gradual reductions in functional exercise capacity (measured by 6MWD) and increasing dyspnea symptoms in BOS patients post-lung transplant, suggesting a decline in walking performance over time. No significant improvements or benefits of walking were reported.
population_specificity: Lung transplant recipients (24 with BOS, 24 without BOS), matched by age, gender, diagnosis, and transplant characteristics.
study_duration: Annual follow-up assessments post-transplant (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-frequency rTMS combined with treadmill training improves gait performance in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that 5Hz rTMS prior to treadmill training significantly improved walking speed, gait symmetry, and lower extremity motor function in the experimental group, with effects persisting for at least 1 month. No significant changes were observed in corticomotor excitability or brain asymmetry ratio.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke
effective_dosage: 5Hz rTMS prior to treadmill training, three times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two different breathing techniques (SDBT and FDBT) using the Voldyne incentive spirometer on pulmonary function in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found no statistical difference in pulmonary function parameters between the two groups before training, but the abstract is incomplete regarding post-intervention results.
population_specificity: 30 COPD patients with mild (stage I) to moderate (stage II) severity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the construct validity of the Wisconsin Gait Scale (WGS) in stroke patients across different recovery stages.
results_summary: The WGS showed moderate construct validity with walking, balance, and functionality scales in acute stroke patients, and excellent correlation with these measures at subacute and chronic stages.
population_specificity: 61 stroke patients in an inpatient rehabilitation setting.
study_duration: Assessed at acute, subacute, and chronic stages (up to 12 months post-stroke).

study_goal: To determine the feasibility and acceptability of using a robotic walking aid (SafeWalker®) to reduce fear of falling in elderly patients with psychomotor disadaptation during rehabilitation.
results_summary: Patients in the intervention group found rehabilitation sessions easier, and no robotic sessions were replaced by conventional ones. No significant differences were found between groups on other outcome measures.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 85.2 years) with psychomotor disadaptation admitted to an academic rehabilitation ward.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore cardiovascular and musculoskeletal changes resulting from a supervised exercise program (SEP) for patients with intermittent claudication and identify predictors of walking distance improvement.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in maximum walking distance, claudication distance, quality of life, cardiorespiratory fitness, and muscle strength/endurance. The ventilatory anaerobic threshold and physical component summary scores from quality of life were the best predictors of walking distance improvement.
population_specificity: Patients (n=109) with intermittent claudication, primarily aged over 70, recruited from a vascular unit in England.
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise program (SEP) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of deep versus moderate neuromuscular blockade (NMB) on surgical outcomes, including the time it takes for patients to begin walking after thoracoscopic lobectomy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between deep and moderate NMB groups in the time it took for patients to begin walking after surgery. Other recovery metrics, blood gas analysis, and hospitalization time were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for thoracoscopic lobectomy under intravenous anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study compared NMB levels, not walking interventions).
study_duration: Not applicable (study focused on surgical and immediate postoperative outcomes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Annurca apple polyphenolic extract (AMS) in improving walking autonomy and other outcomes in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The AMS group showed a 69% increase in walking autonomy, a 25% improvement in ankle-brachial index, and a 3.6% reduction in acceleration time, all statistically significant. The placebo group showed no significant changes in any outcome measures.
population_specificity: 180 patients aged 35-75 with peripheral arterial disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a definitive schedule of gross motor development, including walking, for children with Down syndrome (DS) to help identify delays and guide interventions.
results_summary: The study provided specific ages of mastery for 44 gross motor skills, including walking, with mean, median, and percentile data for children with DS, showing no significant gender differences in skill achievement.
population_specificity: Children with Down syndrome (n = 509) receiving care at two specialized referral centers.
study_duration: Longitudinal data collection (specific duration not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of nutrition therapy on walking ability among older stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of nutrition therapy on walking ability, though it did reduce the incidence of infections.
population_specificity: Older stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of dual-task exercise on dual-task mobility, fall risk, and quality of life in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The dual-task group showed reduced dual-task interference in walking time, maintained improvements at follow-up, and reduced fall risk by 25.0% and injurious falls by 22.2%. No significant effects were observed on cognitive performance, activity participation, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (61.2±6.4 years, mild to moderate motor impairment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gait training with a hip-assistive robotic exoskeleton improves clinical outcomes and corticospinal drive in individuals with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that gait training with the Honda Stride Management Assist (SMA) exoskeleton improved walking speed, endurance, balance, and corticomotor excitability in chronic stroke patients, though walking speed improvements were not significantly greater than intensity-matched functional gait training.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion of adults with cystic fibrosis in Australia who use walking as a substitute for traditional airway clearance techniques and their beliefs about this substitution.
results_summary: Walking was one of the most commonly used forms of exercise among adults with CF, with 44% having substituted exercise (including walking) for traditional airway clearance techniques in the previous 3 months. Personal experience was the primary factor influencing their belief in this substitution.
population_specificity: Adults with cystic fibrosis in Australia (n=692).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interval walking training (IWT) improves cognitive function and arterial function more effectively than normal walking training (NWT) in older adults.
results_summary: Both IWT and NWT significantly improved cognitive function (measured by trail making tests) and reduced arterial stiffness (measured by cfPWV), but IWT showed a greater reduction in arterial stiffness compared to NWT.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 70 ± 4 years)
effective_dosage: IWT: five or more sets of low-intensity walking (3 min at 40% peak aerobic capacity) followed by high-intensity walking (3 min at >70% peak aerobic capacity); NWT: walking at ~50% peak aerobic capacity.

study_goal: To examine the effects of a home-based exercise program, including walking, on quality of life, psychological health, and physical activity levels in colorectal cancer survivors.
results_summary: The home-based exercise program significantly improved quality of life (particularly emotional well-being and physical/functional outcomes) and increased physical activity levels in colorectal cancer survivors, though the change in QOL between groups was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer survivors (71 participants, 58 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Unsupervised walking, stationary bike, or swimming for aerobic exercise, plus resistance exercise DVDs, a pedometer, and an exercise log (specific frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the reliability, validity, and responsiveness of physical capacity tasks, including walking-related tests, for assessing functioning in patients with low back pain.
results_summary: The study found moderate to strong evidence for the reliability and construct validity of walking-related tasks (e.g., 5-minute walk, 50-ft walk) and limited evidence for their responsiveness in patients with chronic low back pain.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the development and effectiveness of vestibular implants in improving vestibular reflexes and functional abilities, such as visual performance during walking, in patients with bilateral vestibular deficits.
results_summary: The study found that vestibular implants can restore vestibular reflexes, particularly the vestibulo-ocular reflex, and improve functional performance in real-world tasks like walking. Human patients demonstrated significant adaptation to artificial vestibular signals.
population_specificity: Patients with bilateral vestibular deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationships between walking ability, emotion, and cognitive impairment in people with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that emotional disturbances (e.g., anxiety, depression) and cognitive impairment contribute to gait disorders in some people with PD, though evidence for the effectiveness of interventions (pharmacological, surgical, physical therapy) in improving locomotion was mixed.
population_specificity: People with Parkinson's disease (PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine lower limb joint angles and angular velocities in healthy adults walking at various speeds to establish normative data for clinical comparisons.
results_summary: The study found that peak joint angles and angular velocities increased with walking speed, with consistent gait trace shapes across speeds. The largest angular velocities occurred during knee extension at terminal swing and ankle/hip movement during push-off.
population_specificity: Thirty-six healthy adult participants.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking speeds ranged from 0.4 m/s to 1.6 m/s in 0.2 m/s increments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of eccentric training (backward-downhill treadmill training) and manual static stretching on gait and muscle function in patients with spastic Cerebral Palsy.
results_summary: Backward-downhill treadmill training improved single stance dorsiflexion and walking speed, while stretching reduced knee flexion during swing. Neither treatment altered muscle-tendon stiffness or strength, though both increased passive muscle and fascicle strain.
population_specificity: 10 ambulatory patients with spastic Cerebral Palsy (aged 12 ± 4 years, 2 unilateral and 8 bilateral cases).
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week for each treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the reliability and normative data for the Timed Up and Go test (TUG) in typically developing children.
results_summary: The study found that TUG time is consistent within and between raters and sessions, influenced by age, and affected by protocol choice, walking speed, motivation, and outcome calculation. A standard TUG protocol is lacking and should be developed with attention to reliability.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 to 18 years who are developing typically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if treadmill walking exercise training improves learning, memory, hippocampal volume, and functional connectivity in cognitively impaired persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results, as the study is ongoing ("Pre-results"), but it outlines the methodology for assessing treadmill walking's effects on cognitive and brain health outcomes in MS patients.
population_specificity: Fully ambulatory persons with MS who have objective learning and memory impairments.
effective_dosage: Supervised treadmill walking exercise training three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) following bacterial meningitis secondary to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) in an adult.
results_summary: The study found that GBS can occur as a rare complication of bacterial meningitis, presenting with limb numbness, weakness, and bladder dysfunction, requiring prolonged assistance with walking. The case highlights the need to consider GBS in bacterial meningitis patients with limb symptoms, especially those with diabetes.
population_specificity: A 46-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and chronic suppurative otitis media.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of onabotulinum toxin A injections on foot dystonia symptoms, including walking difficulties, pain, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in stride length, along with other functional outcomes such as gait velocity, balance, and dystonia severity, as measured by various scales.
population_specificity: Fourteen (14) adult patients with foot dystonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health outcomes of SMA1 infants treated with AVXS-101 gene replacement therapy, including motor function improvements such as walking.
results_summary: Two out of twelve patients achieved independent walking, and eleven patients achieved full head control and sitting unassisted, indicating significant motor function improvement. The treatment was associated with reduced pulmonary and nutritional support requirements and decreased hospitalization rates.
population_specificity: Twelve genetically confirmed SMA1 infants with homozygous deletions of the SMN1 gene and two SMN2 gene copies.
effective_dosage: One-time intravenous proposed therapeutic dose of AVXS-101.
study_duration: Patients were followed for 2 years post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of nocardial spinal epidural abscess with severe lumbar disc herniation and its treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that the patient experienced progressive lumbago and leg pain after acupuncture, followed by urine retention after walking. Surgical intervention and long-term antimicrobial treatment led to full recovery after one year.
population_specificity: A 50-year-old man with nocardial spinal epidural abscess and severe lumbar disc herniation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sociodemographic and clinical predictors of successful community walking ability restoration in stroke survivors 6 months post-stroke.
results_summary: Younger age, early mobilization, good initial walking ability, absence of clinical complications, and female gender were positive predictors for community walking recovery, while risk factors and complications delayed recovery. No correlation was found with gender, lesion side, or aphasia.
population_specificity: 310 stroke survivors admitted to inpatient neuro-rehabilitation centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of a hybrid intervention combining exergaming and physical therapy to improve physical activity and delay disability in older adults.
results_summary: The hybrid intervention significantly improved handgrip strength and Timed Up and Go test scores, with no significant adverse events reported. A notable portion of participants reported physical inactivity, citing laziness, lack of interest, and engagement hassle as common reasons.
population_specificity: Older adults recruited from a long-term care facility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review validated screening tools for cachexia, sarcopenia, and malnutrition in adults and suggest the development of a novel combined screening tool.
results_summary: The study identified 22 validated screening tools, with CASCO for cachexia, SPSM and SARC-F for sarcopenia, and 3-Minute Nutrition Score for malnutrition performing well. No single tool could assess all three conditions simultaneously.
population_specificity: Adults with potential cachexia, sarcopenia, or malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if losartan or omega-3 fish oil could reduce IL-6 levels and improve 400 m walking speed in older adults with mobility impairment and low-grade chronic inflammation.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of losartan or fish oil on IL-6 levels or walking speed, indicating these interventions did not improve mobility in the studied population.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥70 years with mobility impairment, IL-6 levels between 2.5 and 30 pg/mL, and ability to walk 400 m at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding local infiltration of analgesia to femoral nerve block improves pain management and recovery outcomes after total knee arthroplasty compared to femoral nerve block alone.
results_summary: The combination of local infiltration of analgesia and femoral nerve block reduced fentanyl consumption and improved knee range of motion post-operatively, but showed no significant differences in pain scores, quadriceps strength, or functional tests compared to femoral nerve block alone.
population_specificity: Forty patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ropivacaine and dexamethasone for local infiltration, saline for control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and functional outcomes of unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA) versus total knee arthroplasty (TKA) for unicompartmental knee osteoarthritis, focusing on walking distance and other functional metrics.
results_summary: The study found that UKA resulted in better functional outcomes, including longer walking distance, improved joint flexion, and range of motion, compared to TKA. However, UKA had a higher risk of revision surgeries.
population_specificity: Patients with unicompartmental knee osteoarthritis (13,789 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether PR-fampridine has a clinically meaningful effect on self-reported walking ability in walking-impaired individuals with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: PR-fampridine treatment resulted in significantly more participants achieving clinically meaningful improvements in walking ability (MSWS-12 score) and functional measures (TUG speed, MSIS-29 PHYS) compared to placebo over 24 weeks, though some secondary outcomes (BBS/ABILHAND) showed non-significant improvements. Adverse events were more common in the PR-fampridine group but were not severe enough to outweigh benefits.
population_specificity: Walking-impaired adults aged 18-70 with relapsing or progressive multiple sclerosis (EDSS 4.0-7.0).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors determining the effect size of dual-task training on dual-task walking performance in people with Parkinson’s disease.
results_summary: Lower baseline dual-task gait velocity and higher cognitive capacity were associated with greater improvements in dual-task gait velocity after both integrated and consecutive dual-task training across all three tasks. The type of training did not significantly influence the outcomes.
population_specificity: 121 participants with Parkinson’s disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of technology-based distance physical rehabilitation interventions, including walking, on physical functioning in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results for walking outcomes, with technology-based interventions showing similar effects to traditional treatments for other physical functioning measures but no clear efficacy for walking. The methodological quality and evidence were considered low.
population_specificity: Stroke patients
